fields.summary: Dashboarding | Hidden static elements in Implicit Associations Map reappear after saving to Dashboard

content.text: I am attempting to present an Implicit Associations Map in a Dashboard or Report with specific static elements (brands) hidden. While the visibility settings work correctly in the "Analyze" view, these settings are ignored immediately upon saving the chart to a Dashboard or Report, causing all elements to reappear. The user has attempted multiple methods (legend toggle, chart settings, new chart creation) with the same result.
The Implicit Associations Map displays correctly in the "Analyze" view with specific brands hidden.
Upon saving the chart to a Dashboard or Report, the widget reverts to the default state.
All static elements (brands) that were previously hidden become visible again in the saved widget.
The configuration is lost regardless of whether the element was hidden via the Legend "Eye" icon or the main Chart Settings menu.
The "Save to Dashboard" and "Save to Report" actions should capture the exact current state of the chart, including visibility toggles for static elements.
The Dashboard widget should render exactly as the chart appeared in the Analyze view at the moment of saving.
Hidden elements should remain hidden in the destination view unless manually re-enabled.
next to a specific brand to hide it.
Open "Chart Settings" and uncheck the specific brand.
Observe that the brands are successfully hidden in the Analyze view.
Navigate to the resulting Dashboard or Report.
that the widget displays the map with
static elements visible, ignoring the configuration set in Step 4.
I attempted to create a brand new chart from scratch to rule out legacy data issues; the bug persisted.
The payload sent during the "Save" action appears to omit the
array for the static elements, causing the backend to regenerate the chart with default parameters.

status.description: This issue is being actively worked on at the moment by the assignee.
status.name: In Progress

fields.summary: BBHT - Update Network Size's Hover Text Box to Relevant Data Points

content.text: Right now when hovering over a data point in a Network Size chart, it only shows the average (Network Size) and a “Wave Selects” data point. However, this Wave Selects data point is irrelevant to the Network Size calculation.
The two data points that actually make the Network Size are “Brand Selects” and “MPen Respondents” (Calculated as Brand Selects / MPen Respondents).
A client specifically raised this issue since they were confused why it shows this total Wave Selects when it’s not a part of the calculation.
Conversely, Mental Market Share and Mental Penetration both accurately show the data points required for their calculation. For instance:
MMS (Calculated as Brand Selects / Wave Selects):
MPen (Calculated as MPen Respondents / Group Total):

To accurately show the data points for Network Size, we just need to show the “Brand Selects” data point that is shown in the MMS chart, along with the top # from MPen that indicates the MPen Respondents.
So we’d expect the Hover Text to show as:

fields.summary: Editor | Semi-Monadic / Dynamic Looping | Allow randomization of items when a CV is the source

content.text: We had the situation in which our client Pepsi wanted to only use a relevant subset of known brands in the dynamic looping block. Currently this demand needs to be realized with a CV that only includes the relevant brands from the awareness question.
But if a CV is the source for the dynamic looping block, the order of brands is always static as implemented in the CV and not randomized.
→ the expectation or feature request is that if a CV is the source that still all drawn categories are randomized in the looping block.
the awareness questions contains 8 brands (A - H) but only 3 brands (A + B + C)are relevant to be drawn for the looping block
therefore a CV is created that contains three groups (A + B + C)
In the looping block there is a consstent order as always brand A is the first loop, brand B the second loop and brand C the third loop (no randomization as the client expected / hoped for).

→ it is not a solution to draw directly three brands from the awareness question and always include these three brands as this does not ensure that only these three relevant brands are applicable for the drawing but also other brands. Hence a CV is required.

→ we also tried the workaround to use the “Multi Matrix with one column” dummy workaround but the “Multi Matrix” is not available as a source questions. Hence a solution could be to allow a “Multi matrix with one column” to be the source for dynamic looping.

fields.summary: Unexpected Complete Count Fluctuations in Tracker

content.text: We’re noticing some unusual behavior with this tracker and wanted to flag it. Earlier this morning, the study was at approximately
. We were later able to reach
, but shortly after, it appeared that we lost about
Now, upon checking again, we’re seeing
, which is unexpected since the maximum total for this study is
. We’re not sure how an additional ~800 respondents were able to come through beyond the cap.

It seems like there may be something off with the platform—potentially allowing additional respondents through—and when we apply the cleaner flag, we see a significant drop in completes, though those respondents then appear to re-surface later. At this point, we’re unsure what’s driving these fluctuations.
If someone could take a look and help identify what might be happening, that would be greatly appreciated.

fields.summary: Enable Cross-Element Significance Testing & Wave Tracking for Loops

content.text: Users need the ability to apply
levels of a looped rating matrix. Currently, selecting "All (Comparison)" disables the "Wave Split" functionality (as seen in the attached screenshot), forcing users into inefficient workarounds.
When a user selects "All (Comparison)" to view all looped items (brands) side-by-side, the system treats this as the maximum number of split levels.
Consequently, the "Wave Split" toggle (bottom left of the screenshot) becomes grayed out/unavailable.
Users are forced to view only one brand at a time to enable wave tracking.
Allow users to filter to a specific row of a rating matrix (single attribute) and track
(Top 2 Box) against each other, with the ability to split/track by Wave simultaneously.
Without this feature, the user faces significant reporting obstacles:

To track data for 12 brands, the user currently has to build 12 separate charts (one per brand) rather than just 4 charts (one per attribute). This drastically increases dashboard building time and complexity.
By forcing the user to split charts by individual brand, they lose the ability to perform

fields.summary: [Analysis & Visualization] | Data Discrepancy in Keyword Analysis (Top-of-Mind vs Total)

content.text: [Analysis & Visualization] | Data Discrepancy | Top-of-Mind values exceeding Total Unaided Awareness for specific keywords

In the project “Thüringer Waldquell Tracking” (Hassia Group), the keyword recognition for "Waldquell" is inconsistent across different waves. In some periods (e.g., 2024), the Top-of-Mind (ToM) values are higher than the Total values, indicating an algorithmic discrepancy that threatens tracking consistency and historical comparability.
The logic "Total >= ToM" is violated in specific timeframes (e.g., January 2024 / Full Year 2024) for the keyword "Waldquell".
The system sometimes counts "Waldquell" (when part of "Thüringer Waldquell") in the first row for ToM, but maybe fails to count it in the Total aggregate for the same wave.
The client reports that the "Waldquell" keyword was historically mostly
identified/counted when appearing as the second word in that specific phrase. The current "inflated" ToM values in 2024 deviate from this established baseline.
The keyword matching must function identically across all waves and all chart types (ToM vs. Total).
To maintain tracking stability, the algorithm should align with the historical behavior expected by the client (where "Waldquell" in "Thüringer Waldquell" was typically not counted).
Under no circumstances should the ToM value exceed the Total value.

Compare "Ungestützte Markenbekanntheit nach Jahren" (Total) with "Top of Mind Markenbekanntheit (ungestützt) nach Jahren" (ToM) or "Markenbekanntheit (ungestützt)  - Verlauf" (Total) with "Top of Mind Marken (Bekanntheit ungestützt)  - Verlauf" (ToM).
Observe that ToM is higher than Total, contradicting both logic and historical data patterns.
Compare this to older waves where the keyword was consistently not counted, showing the deviation in 2024.
The client expects the lower/historical (or consistent) counting method to be applied everywhere to ensure year-over-year comparability.

The algorithm is likely "over-detecting" in the ToM (Row 1) logic for recent data while remaining "strict" in the Total aggregation logic. We need to identify why the detection behavior changed in 2024.
As this is a tracking project, data consistency across waves is the highest priority.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct.

fields.summary: Is it possible to change the source question of a looping block and retain existing data?

content.text: Situation: There is a dynamic looping block in the survey, with source question being Q25 (p6M purchase - multi select), and the looped questions being Q32 to Q35.

We want to see if it is possible to change the source question to Q24 (ever purchased  - also a multi select), without overwriting the rest of the data. We want to be able to send new respondents through the survey and see if the data for Q32-Q35 will become aggregated in the same charts/questions. The ideal situation is that we can move the sourcing question to Q24, keeping the data for Q32-Q35 intact and adding new respondents.

Essentially using Q25 for the source question is too restrictive, so we want to use Q24 instead to open up to a wider pool of responses. This is a tracker and we already collected wave 1 data, so looking to keep that intact. I flagged this as a Hotfix because we need to re-field a portion of this study so we want to make this change ASAP so we can get it back into field.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: question about piped text. Is it captured anywhere?

content.text: Client's DIY project had a long list of claims, and they used a series of HVs to pipe one at random into a likes/dislikes OE. The HV doesn't contain data in analyze or the raw data export. Is there any way I can recover this info for her?

”I'm trying to determine which claim each respondent was assigned for the like/dislike OEs, which was determined by US Hidden Var 1-3 (Q30-Q32) and MX Hidden Var 1-3 (Q46-48) respectively. However, when I look at those variables in the platform, theres no data and when I export to excel, N/A in every column.”

I already reached out on platform-exchange and established this was not a good set up, and learned how to tell the client to set it up next time. For this current project, the client is pushing back on my explanation that the piped text was not captured / can’t be recovered.

“please double check that there is not a variable on the server database that captures what is assigned. In my experience, a variable is typically created in these scenarios in the database itself though it might not be a variable read in to the platform. I highly suspect there is a variable considering the KPI assignment of 10 claims was effective in creating a subset of 10 claims. This subset has to be recorded somewhere in order for the same 10 claims to be piped into every KPI question.”
As far as I know, we don’t have this anywhere, but I want to double-check as she requested.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct.

fields.summary: Multi Country / Editor | Auto Translate strips <source> tags and corrupts HTML attributes, breaking video playback

content.text: Our customer 'OMG HH' and internal testing confirmed that running the "Auto Translate" feature corrupts any video element within surveys that are translated using it. This affects both questions targeted by the auto-translation and questions that were already manually translated (and should therefore be ignored by auto-translation). Once Auto Translate is executed, videos become unplayable in all views (Editor, Preview, Participant) and cannot be deleted from the translation editor.
Observed Behavior (after auto translation a survey that has videos in it)
tag is completely removed after translation, leaving an empty video container.
attribute quotes are malformed (changed from single
), breaking the JSON syntax and preventing the player from reading the video ID.
Due to the missing source and broken ID, the video does not load or play in Editor, Preview, or Participant views.
The corrupted HTML structure likely creates a cursor trap, preventing the element from being selected/deleted in the Translation Editor.
The Auto Translate parser must ignore HTML tags and attributes (especially
) and only translate inner text content and JSON strings inside HTML attributes (using single quotes wrappers) must be preserved exactly as is.
Videos should remain playable in all views after translation automation runs.
Video elements should remain deletable in the Translation Editor
Create a new survey project (or copy an existing one with a video in it).
(Optional) Manually translate this question into a second language (e.g., German to English) to confirm it works initially.
At this stage, confirm the video plays correctly and can be deleted in the translation editor.
The video element is now broken and does not play.
Open the Translation Editor for that question.
Attempt to delete the video element; the action fails.
The translation service appears to be sanitizing or re-serializing HTML using a rule set that does not support HTML5 video tags or JSON-in-attributes correctly.
There are workarounds available. However, the non-functional videos have to be re-uploaded no matter what:
The video height/width can be set to 0px to hide the broken element
The question can be manually re-created entirely with a new video uploaded, as long as Auto Translate isn’t used again.
In the translation CSV the HTML code displaying the video can be deleted. If re-uploaded, the video can be deleted this way.
We initially hypothesized this was a
issue similar to text editing bugs. However, for media wrappers,
is required for block deletion. Auto Translate likely corrupts the container HTML, causing the browser to enter the element (cursor trap) rather than selecting the block.
The attached video demonstrates the "Before" (working) and "After" (bricked) states upon running the auto-translation.
‘OMG HH' reported this video initially in
, but there we weren’t able to pin down the  issue. Only after hinting to the Auto Translate feature in
, we did some more testing and were able to reproduce the issue. This has also been reproduced with
test project in my own company.
This issue is similar and could be connected to this ticket:
. The linked OMG project is actually the first project which is linked above as well, but there we didn’t know that this was due to Auto Translate feature.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: Analyze / Data Import: CVs based on Imported Variables (IVs) fail to auto-update until manually viewed in Editor

content.text: The customer YouGov (or rather their end client Digitec Galaxus) reports that Custom Variables dependent on Imported Variables are not updating automatically when the IV data changes. This appears to be a regression of a previously fixed issue from 2020 (
After updating an IV with new data (uploading new participant answers), charts and dashboards using a dependent Custom Variable do not reflect the changes.
The data displayed remains in the state prior to the IV update (stale data).

The calculation update is triggered simply by navigating to the CV Editor and expanding the specific variable/category. Unlike previous workarounds, no actual change or "Save" action is required to force the update. Just "viewing" the logic seems sufficient to trigger the refresh.
When an underlying IV is updated via file upload, all dependent Custom Variables should recalculate automatically.
Charts in the Analyze and Report sections should reflect the new data immediately without requiring the user to open the CV settings manually.
Create (or ensure existence of) a CV logic based on this IV.
Check the current data distribution in an Analyze chart.
Go to Data Import and update the IV by uploading a modified dataset (new participant answers).
Navigate back to the Analyze/Report section.
The charts still show the old data distribution (data did not update).
Navigate to Project Settings -> Custom Variables.
Click to open/expand the specific CV category (Note: no need to actually make changes, just expand the view).
The numbers in the CV are immediately updated and charts are now also updated with the correct figures.
Confirmed in the linked project above, unknown if this is a global issue.

As there is a workaround (manual re-triggering), this is not particularly urgent. However, the client already raised a formal complaint due to the weighting not working in most of the past waves. Also this issue was already present for them in the past and we took over manual retriggering of all updated CVs for them.

status.description: This issue is being actively worked on at the moment by the assignee.
status.name: In Progress

fields.summary: Analyze | Key Driver Analysis (KDA) fails to calculate due to BSONObj size limit

content.text: Our customer YouGov (&their end client On) is attempting to perform a Key Driver Analysis, but receives a “Calculation Failed” error regardless of the chosen sample size. This behavior is reproducible in both the new Analyze and the Legacy Analyze areas.

In the new Analyze area the KDA calculation always fails when using the total sample and even when using heavily reduced sub-samples (reproduced with n=232 participants). In the legacy Analyze area, the calculation for the total sample fails as well, but for smaller samples, waiting does result in the chart eventually being loaded.
In new Analyze the following error is immediately displayed:
Calculation failed: BSONObj size: 19194052 (0x124E0C4) is invalid. Size must be between 0 and 16793600 (16MB) First element: code: 10334

. Reducing the amount of drivers removed the initial error message and instead displayed the error "Calculation failed: Failed to fetch" after loading for a while, even with a smaller sample (~10k in total, but for the KDA only n=2779 are included in the calculation, see screenshot below).
In Legacy Analyze, for those samples that eventually load, this misleading error message appears during the loading process:
An error occurred or your selection has less than 50 valid participants. Please try again or contact customer success.
The data size specified in the error message (~19MB) is consistent, regardless of the chosen sub-sample, raising the hypothesis that the total data volume might be entering the analysis pipeline.
The Key Driver Analysis should be calculated and displayed correctly for all valid samples with at least 50 valid participants.

The data aggregation for the analysis should be designed to operate within the fixed technical BSONObj size limit of 16MB, as this is an unchangeable, hard-coded technical limit of the MongoDB architecture.

No error messages should be displayed upon successful calculation in Analyze 1. The error message should only appear if the sample size is actually too small or if there is an error that leads to the results not being calculated.
with a focus on the item
Run the calculation for the total sample (Total Basis).
, the loading spinner appears, followed by the misleading error
An error occurred or your selection has less than 50 valid participants
Apply a heavily reduced sample, e.g., the customer's sample
is still displayed, despite the significantly reduced data volume and nothing loads. In
, the loading spinner appears, followed by the above described error message, but the chart loads eventually.

, 10K participants is the maximum with which we can still calculate a KDA. However, it fails also for samples way below that. Also the error message doesn’t say anything about a limit of 10k per calculation, making this hard to figure out for clients.
Also, if there is indeed this technical limit, how is it possible that the charts do still load in A1 at some point for configurations that do not load at all in the new Analyze version at all?
I have no feedback yet if the client can work with the charts that do load in Analyze 1. I’ll confirm with them and add this later on, but the urgency might actually be higher.

status.description: This issue is being actively worked on at the moment by the assignee.
status.name: In Progress

fields.summary: Analyze: Pin "Exclusive Answers" automatically to the bottom of the list

fields.summary: Pre-Survey Defense | IDs as "finished" in raw data which have a "failreason"

content.text: Hence the expectation is that an ID that was detected as “potential fraud” by the system should not be “finished” in the raw data set.

Data collection was completed as all Entry Links collcted n = 750 participants. But then the panel manager found n = 12 IDs that were redirected back via the fourth redirect link with a “failreason” but are stored as “finished” in the raw data set:
In addition, there seems to be a “failreason=22” which does not make any sense given the fact that we only capture seventeen reasons coded 02-18.
→ can you tell what this reason is and why it was captured?
So the two main questions are:
Why are these n = 12 IDs captured as “finished” while seemingly the system detected them via the “pre-survey defense” feature?
Why is there a reason (22) that we, at least according to the
, do not cover? And what does it mean?

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: Conjoints with Sample Sizes below 100

content.text: Hello Science team!! wanted to get your perspective on a conjoint edge case - I am meeting with an  medical device prospect who wants to run conjoints with us. She mentioned that their typical sample size is n=50-75, which she understands is low and is comfortable with the fact that the insights won't be quite as robust. On
I saw that we don't recommend going below n=100 for conjoint. My question is:

Is there an absolute minimum sample size that we need to hit for the estimation to work from a technical perspective (I know its n=50 for TURF but I can't find on confluence if thats true for conjoint too)?
Would we feel comfortable reporting out on a sample size of n=50-75 if the client has the right perspective that this is a very directional read?

content.text: We’re working on a study where the typing tool doesn’t seem to be functioning correctly. We have respondents who qualified as renters at Q10—about 45% selected that they have rented. Based on the typing tool logic, these respondents should be assigned to Segment 2 or Segment 4. However, they are not being placed into any renter segments.

The client did make some minor wording changes to Q10, but not to the answer options, so those edits shouldn’t affect the typing tool logic or prevent renters from being assigned to the correct segments. We need the typing tool to function properly, as quotas will be set based on these segments. We’ve paused fielding for now.
Could someone look into this and help identify what might be causing the issue?

fields.summary: Typing tool feasibility for Amgen- Consumer and HCP

content.text: Our new client Amgen has standard screeners that we are building into the app as templates.

Their screening questions seem to have complex logic, which will need integration via typing tool. We  are sharing details below for the consumer audience and HCP audience, both of which are based on different questions. Could you let us know feasibility for these and how soon we can have these integrated.
Unfortunately we did not have any discussion around these during pre-sales and the client wants to field these surveys at the earliest.

Consumer audience: We need a typing tool that calculates the BMI index based on height and weight input (screenshot below). While number input question seems to be compatible with the New TT, our thinking was to set these questions as a single select drop down to avoid responses that may be difficult to interpret later example if people don’t type in inches properly. But let us know your thoughts on if using number input is suggested here and has worked in the past for such question types.
HCP Audience: For the HCP audience we need sum based on the question screenshot below. We set these questions as number input question types (randomized in different blocks). Will that set up work?

fields.summary: A/B-test | Performance Issues - Extreme Delay (15-20sec) on First Load of A/B Test Images in Participant View

content.text: Our client YouGov noticed performance issues in the participant view where images in A/B tests, experience extremely long loading times when displaying the image for the first time. The core problem appears to be related to the initial caching/compression process, and the original fix (
), which reduced image size upon upload, has not fully resolved the issue, as it now also has been observed in a simpler ad-hoc project with fewer monads in each A/B-test and images in general.
When a participant reaches a page containing an image or video within an A/B test, the loading time can be excessively long for the first call of the image (observed at 15-20 seconds per image).
The survey page structure appears first, but the media assets (images) only load significantly later.
This issue is not consistently reproducible after the first few test rounds, as subsequent loads are likely faster due to caching (at least according to the explanation in
Pages with media, even those within A/B tests, should load all elements within an acceptable performance range (~1 second) for the first load, as per the verification of the previous fix.
The page and all images/videos should appear simultaneously.
The "Next" button on pages with a fixed exposure duration should only become interactable
the media asset has fully loaded

There are no concrete ‘Steps to reproduce’ this issue, as the study had to be fielded and it’s not clear if the images were already loaded by testing from us, the client and their end client. Furthermore, it is the nature of this bug that it cannot be reproduced indefinitely.
This issue affectes only images in A/B tests, as there were no images implemented in regular Open Text questions.

The "Next" button for a fixed-duration exposure (e.g., 10 seconds) becomes visible long before the actual image/video asset is displayed, allowing the participant to proceed before the required exposure time is met and in our instance even long before the image was displayed at all.

A temporary workaround is to manually click through all A/B test groups to pre-cache the images for all participants, but this is an unacceptable manual effort, especially if it should be the ‘standard procedure’ in this case.
Because of this workaround, the issue is probably solved for now.

, was intended to resolve this by reducing uploaded images to a maximum of 1920px width. This new behavior suggests either the fix is not fully effective, or the initial image compression/caching process is still too slow.
This was already reported in these tickets:

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: pls support with an export API related question reg file size

content.text: It is me once again with an API-related question.
I am [name] writing to you on behalf of Team Omni who is responsible for the [project].

We would like to inform you that the JSON file sent to us for December exceeds the recommended file size limit of 128 MB. The file received yesterday is 176 MB, which prevented successful processing. As a result, the reporting system currently does not have up-to-date NPS data.
Could you please advise whether it is possible to reduce the file size so that processing can proceed as expected?
Thank you for your time and attention to this matter.
Can you help me answer this?
My first idea would be that they have to change the prompt they use for downloading the file to not include all data but only the new data points but not sure whether that is too easy.
Please also let me know whether I need to ask them something back for us to understand.
has also been addressed with this mail but still writing this for visibility and not sure whether it is actually his call to answer this!

fields.summary: C&A NPS Tracking

content.text: in all stores (1,300) + newsletter customers again this year. The survey ran for the first time this year and currently has 142,000 completes and is running very stable.
Here is the description of the project scope for
C&A set up the NPS survey in one project. The Entry Link is distributed via a QR Code / receipt / sticker / display stands in the stores and additionally send to newsletter subscribers.
We expect approx. 50,000 - 60,000 completes per month - approx. 650,000 per year.
The analysis/reporting is currently done via Data Download per API and Dashboards (currently 4).
We already discussed the following framework conditions with C&A and Luca & Morris last year and got your go-ahead:
C&A is clearly and deliberately aware that it is not a quantilope standard - for them, it is a clear test project.
They would first start slowly with a test phase only in

(Germany, Austria, Switzerland), so that during the course of the project, before huge amounts of data arrive, we can assess what to expect and how many projects we need to keep the data volume under control. It is estimated that a maximum of
They would only collect the data via quantilope (if necessary) and analyze it externally via API.
They are open to deleting cases starting from 100k cases (?), if the project becomes too large.
They are open to setting this up in separate projects per region from the start.
We spoke transparently and said that it is also a test again in 2026.
What is your assessment of this?
Can we offer this again in 2026 with 650,000 completes per year? Which limitations can occur?

fields.summary: Conjoint Questions from Prospect

content.text: Hi Science team!! I got a few questions from a prospect about conjoint designs - could you please advise?

Is there a way to see the 'main effects' within a conjoint design? Or the number of times each level is shown per respondent? How would these elements impact sample size (i.e., if the client said I want every level shown to each respondent at least 5 times or with a main effect under 0.05, can we reverse engineer the proper sample size)?
Does our conjoint design tell us the standard error for main effects and interaction effects (based on the sample size, # of concepts per task, number of tasks etc.)?
Does our conjoint do a share of preference approach in the modeling or a ‘first choice ’approach?

I’m happy to spar over a call with whoever picks this request up too, curious what the data looks like.

fields.summary: ACCELERATE: New Editor Multi-Country Parity (Blocking Adoption & Revenue)

content.text: Dear Product Team especially the New Editor Team,

I know multi-country support for the new editor is a priority. Following an informal conversation with Morris this week and an official “product talk” with Jayne in October (who mentioned a potential Q1 release in October), I formally request accelerating multi-country feature parity with the legacy editor or a version that mirrors the essential multi-country functions and capabilities of the legacy editor as fast as possible.

The background for this is, that we have a lot of (DIY) customers that really like the new updates that we’re giving them in our meetings, but their enthusiasm quickly turns into frustration when they realize they cannot use these updates due to their need for multi-country surveys
To provide some more background for this:
(source: amplitude - event: language added) who added a language to a questionnaire and couldn’t use the New Editor for their projects.
We have received direct feedback that other projects couldn’t be realizied in quantilope since features / methods like looping and sequential A/B testing is only available in the New Editor.

At least I’m facing some hard times for pricing negotiations, since we increased the platform pricing significantly, but when clients cannot access the value of the newest features negotiations are quite difficult .

And last, but not least, a faster / direct solution directly supports our Q4 OKR: "We have driven platform adoption so that 250 projects have leveraged both the New Survey Editor and the New Analyze."
Quick multi-country parity is the single biggest step to remove this block and immediately drive New Editor adoption.
I’ve already added my customers as feedback sources to the ticket, but would expect that further sources will be added soon.
Could you please review the possibility of accelerating multi-country support in the New Editor?
Please let me know if you have any further questions.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: Rank order where they don't rank all - stacked bar chart needs to be based among all, NOT rebased to those who ranked that item

content.text: For a client, we included a Q where respondents ranked their top three items in a ten-item list.
When charted, the platform shows the data for each row BASED to the respondents who ranked that item in their top 3, so the chart bars all sum to 100.
In the tooltip for each row, I can see each row has a different base, rather than all rows being calc’d among the 300 respondents I’m looking at.

This should be charted like this, so we can see both A) for what % of respondents was each item in their top 3 and B ) the first/second/third breakdown within each. If there is a use case for the above chart, I don’t know it. I’ve always reported on Top X of Y items like the below.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: MaxDiff (HB) | question on utilities

content.text: Our agency client bluedog conducted a study with the MaxDiff (HB) module. After collecting data they went into their analysis and had the following questions which I was able to answer already (but wanted to provide the full scope):
note: if you scroll down to the end of the ticket, you find the summarized questions)
Can you please help me understand what the difference is and how to use the individual level raw data for the HB Max-Diff exercises?
I noticed that my raw data Excel export includes a worksheet called “Part-worths” and a worksheet called “Scores” for each of the Max-Diff exercises in the study.
I know when I look at analyze in Quantilope I can see the Max-Diff probability scores bar charts that sum to 100, I’m just curious how to interpret the raw excel data
my answer was based on the following two KB articles:
, they posed the following questions, for better understanding and background again the full correspondence:
“Thanks so much for the detailed explanation.

Looking at the data, we are a bit surprised by how tight the spread is between the barrier scores for each of the 4 max-diff exercises (e.g., Max Score of 5%, Min Score 2% for the Food Max-Diff Q4). Looking at the raw data of part-worths illustrates much more spread, both at an individual level (e.g. Q41 participant 33 has min = -2.7 , max = 3.4 ) and on average (Q41 avg min = -39.2 , avg max = 34.7) .

When we’ve done barriers testing in the past (not as a max-diff, but a select all), we’ve seen more spread between the different barriers indicating that some are markedly more important than others. It does seem this type of spread exists within the part-worths but gets lost when translated into scores.
This has led us to a few additional questions for you:
What is the score difference typically expected in a HB-method Max-Diff?

We are curious for the "ratio-scaled” step to get the scores to add to 100, are there assumptions that we can make that will drive a bigger, but still consistent difference between the top utility values and bottom utility values.  What assumptions/transformations in the ratio-scaled step are bringing the lower utility scores up closer to the highest utility percentages on the re-basing to 100? Is the ratio-scaling linearly based or exponential or something else?
And another question related to our questions above:

We noticed that different respondents have quite different degrees of spread in their utility values. Can you help us better understand what that means? Does it mean some people had stronger opinions? Were some people not consistent/paying as much attention?
Is there or should there be more or less weight given to people who show larger spread in utility value?
to sum it up for you, here the questions I would love to get an answer:
What is the score difference typically expected in a HB-method Max-Diff?

-> assuming the answer here will be that a generalization is very difficult as each MaxDiff (hb-based) module is individual and a comparison across different modules is not quite possible (as each module has a different sample structure, number and complexity of items, design etc.).
What assumptions/transformations in the ratio-scaled step are bringing the lower utility scores up closer to the highest utility percentages on the rebasing to 100?
Is the ratio-scaling linearly based or exponential or something else?
Participants have quite different degrees of spread in their utility values. Can you help us better understand what that means?
Does it mean some people had stronger opinions?
Were some people not consistent/paying as much attention?
How is this spread taken incot account when generating the MaxDiff Scores?
Is there or should there be more or less weight given to people who show larger spread in utility value?
Looking forward to reply. If anything unclear. It is about this

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: Survey Editor | Subtle color difference (#2c2e39 instead of #333333) on specific answer items despite explicit color setting

content.text: Multiple clients and our internal QA and service partner DWIse have reported a subtle but persistent UI issue within the Survey Editor affecting the visual appearance of answer items (
). Specific items are rendered in a slightly lighter gray (allegedly
) instead of the intended color (darker gray
) in the Participant View and Preview, and this unwanted color property cannot be resolved via standard editing controls.
Specific answer items within Single Select and Multi Select question types display a subtle color deviation in the Participant View and Preview.
The affected items render in a dark gray (approx.
) instead of the explicitly set color (e.g., darker gray
In the WYSIWYG Editor/Color Picker, the hex codes for both the correctly colored items and the affected items are identical, indicating the issue is a rendering/styling problem, not a data issue.
Attempting to manually change the color to anything else or resetting the formatting of the affected item in the Survey Editor fails to correct the color in the Participant View & Preview.
Answer items should consistently render in the color explicitly set using the platform's color picker.
The color properties of an item should be fully editable and correctable using the provided color picker.
Users should not need to delete and recreate an answer item to fix a styling issue.
Navigate to the Survey Editor and activate Editing Mode.
Click the Eye icon (Preview) in the top right corner of the question block to open the question preview.
Observe: Answer items are displayed in two subtly different colors (e.g., “Personalization” in darker gray, “Avoiding waste” in lighter gray).
Close the Preview and return to the question; unfold the question to edit the items.
Select one of the light gray items and one of the darker gray items.
For each, open the WYSIWYG Editor's Color Picker/Colors menu and note that both items show the exact same hex code (e.g.,
The issue has been observed across multiple studies, including large
projects that are not yet editable in Editor 2. For those projects, the items affected are slightly off in the base language and all translations.

An export of the translation file confirmed that the affected items have no inline CSS and at maximum only contain standard paragraph (

) tags as HTML codes, suggesting an external/default style sheet or platform-level property is overriding the intended color.
The only currently known workaround is deleting the affected item and recreating it entirely.

In Multi-Country projects (like the one linked to this ticket with 27 languages), the workaround can be really time consuming, as deleting an item in the base language necessitates re-adding or re-translating it across dozens of languages. And that is after one has to go through the survey thoroughly to even know which items to delete and recreate.
If the project is already in field, this workaround cannot be used due to the data already collected being lost (luckily no such case until now).

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct.
status.name: Closed
